üí¨For the past few days/weeks, I've been completely immersed in Kingdom Come Deliverance 2, and the game has captivated me in almost every aspect.

üéÆThe storyline unfolds somewhat later from the climax of the original story. Henry as well as Jan Ptacek are trying to communicate a vital message regarding the insurrection against King Sigismund, but a robbery of their property leads them to the Trosky Castle's fortifications without any gear or official papers.

The narrative develops through three parts: Trosky, Kutn√° Hora, and the end. The tale is rich in tension, treason, and sensational scenes - the whole spectrum from the saving of Ptacek to the stunning conclusion with the coming of the allied army. The account is made in a way that follows a logical sequence and is easy to comprehend even if one is not very familiar with the political situation of the medieval times.

The siege of the fortress is definitely striking, especially when there isn't much hope left and the supplies are close to being exhausted. It does not exclude anyone, the audience has to sympathize with the characters for they are in the same situation as the characters have to go through their hardships. 
The whole storyline could be compared to the movies of Guy Ritchie. A bunch of robbers with a good heart comes up with the most extravagant schemes, but everything ends in chaos!

The main combat system has undergone minor changes in its design. Moreover, it has been enriched with the addition of new weapons such as polearms, crossbows, broadswords, and boomsticks (squeakers). Henceforth, combat has been more dynamic - leg strikes have been changed to abdomen thrusts, and counterattacks demand higher skill levels. The interaction of the enemies is more natural and the impact of damage is quite apparent. To summarize, the whole combat experience is more dynamic compared to the one in the first game.

The new features consist of weapon forging, the option to walk through bushes, and various random encounters along the way - from unfortunate bandits to a frightening meeting with the "Death."

The world's response to your actions is, in fact, the most remarkable part. Support a needy person - he could come back to you later with a good deed. Misbehave with a trader of great importance - expect to be charged extra or to lose completely your access to scarce items. Your adventures are talked about everywhere, and the quest choices (even insignificant ones) can surprise you with their consequences at the most unanticipated times. I helped some refugees to get rid of the bandits once, and then they took part in the defense of a castle - such events are just too intriguing for me.

The ending and the fate of certain characters hinge on past choices even in situations that initially seemed to be of little importance. This gives the impression of a genuinely vibrant world, not merely a list of missions.

Although the graphics are not significantly different from those in previous versions, the Czech scenery still looks great. The atmosphere is especially created by the towns and fortresses. The music is right on spot with the plot, and the optimization is really great - the game works without a hitch even on average computers. One curious thing is the different menu splash screen that changes according to your level of play. 
Additionally, the technical side has almost no problems, thus being considered almost perfect.

Amazement comes with the world's detail and size; the game is mapped out quite extensively with a lot of missions and a wide array of activities.

[h3] Kingdom Come: Deliverance - Peasant Simulator Part II [/h3]

[b] Pros [/b]
- Realistic environments and landscapes. Clear attention to detail.
- Superb art style throughout the game, as well as its UI elements.
- Autosave features are of help in some instances.
- Appropriate OST that's in tune with the setting and the lore of the game. 
- Documentation provided, as well as player statistics. Much appreciated!
- Historical references to real-world places, people and events.
- Satisfying conclusions to long-winded side-quests which may/may not tie into the main questline. 
- Various cultures represented, though quasi-idealistically and with a somewhat modern interpretation.
- Non-violent/Pacifist method for enemy takedowns.
- Wabbits are fast. Accurate, both historically and presently. 
- Body decomposition present for previously hunted forest animals.
- Average load time (47 seconds) from desktop shortcut to in-game start.
- Not a single crash to desktop throughout my playtime.
- Cats and mice/rats have been added to the game. This is compared to KCD1, where no cats were ever present. 

[b] Cons [/b]
- Combat system still takes some getting used to. There are ways around this with poison arrows but in the beginning it's rough. 
- Auto-brewing alchemical potions is not allowed in this game, compared to KCD1. A shame, considering the complexity of some recipes. 
- No quicksave feature or manual save unless you use saviour schnapps. No difficulty scaling feature to remove this in the options, either. 
- Limited inventory space for hoarding enthusiasts.
- Facial animations are done well but sometimes the eyes wander aimlessly towards the end of the conversation. 
- Regular voice lines and story lines have different voice actors for some NPCs. Mainly affects miscellaneous quests.
- No option to skip long story-related horse rides.

[b] Bugs [/b]
- Rabbits going/running backwards. Amusing but immersion breaking.
- Very rarely rocks can be seen slightly levitating above the ground.
- KCD1 had a bug where adding a stolen item over normal items of the same type made them all appear stolen. This has been solved here.
- When numbers change in the UI, Nvidia's DLSS lags behind a bit.
- Instead of sitting on a bench, some NPCs prefer to magically levitate above the table (rare).
- Rarely boars run as if on a treadmill when attempting to flee uphill. 

[b] Suggestions [/b]
- More story expansions and improvements to existing DLCs, as well as game mechanics. 
- Major expansion/overhaul to crafting skills where more historical items are added that can be made, sold and used in the environment/settlement/home. Pottery, brewery, weaving, enhanced cooking, beekeeping, mining, etc. Also falconry, like the houndmaster skill line.
- Increase in the variety of plants/insects/birds/animals both local and exotic. 
- Events, festivals, guilds, secret societies, enhanced pilgrimages and music instruments, as well as skill lines for them. 
- A Winter/Autumn based area in which a side story takes place.
- Thunderstorms should present danger even if environmental. Hail, gale, morning dew, heatwaves during peak hours and floods could also be added or hinted at.
- Nighttime overhaul, astronomy and related perks after certain books are read and a certain scholarship level is attained. 
- Medieval dentistry RPG mechanics for tooth loss after fights, potions for bad breath after certain/spoiled foods, etc. 
- Survival mode refinements; adding illnesses both current and historical for immersion purposes.
- Speedrun refinements and special optional challenges associated with that. 
- Permadeath mode and a separate one hit kill mode.
- God mode for players who wish to experience the story without any fuss. 
- Monk mode. No meat, no fighting unless attacked, no crossbows or guns, no poisons, etc. 
- More platforming sections like "Devil's Finger" with misc lore books or rewards.
- Lastly, I triple dare you to add a native Linux build and support for X86, ARM and RISC-V architectures down the line. You know you want to.

From the moment I started playing, it became clear that this game is extremely fun, ridiculously immersive, and probably the best RPG I‚Äôve played this year. Instead, every system (combat, survival, traveling, reputation) works together to make the world feel alive and believable. When you‚Äôre walking through a town or riding through the countryside, it hits you how much detail was put into making this world feel real.

I‚Äôm not really the type of person who spends a ton of time on long, story-heavy games. I usually jump between different games pretty fast. So I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôll actually manage to finish Kingdom Come II, but that doesn‚Äôt take anything away from how good it is. Even if I end up taking forever to beat it (or never finish at all lol), the experience I‚Äôve had so far has been absolutely worth it.

For anyone who enjoys medieval settings, realism, and games that don‚Äôt treat the player like they need constant guidance, this is a huge recommendation. The world reacts to you, progression feels earned, and the gameplay has weight to it. It‚Äôs refreshing in a market where most RPGs go for flashy magic and fast combat, Kingdom Come II stays grounded, and that‚Äôs exactly what makes it so special.

Whether you stick around for the long haul or just jump in for the immersive experience, this game delivers. For me, it‚Äôs easily one of the standout RPGs of the year.

It's good. It's well-made, reeks of passion and polish all the way down. But it just isn't for me, and I'd wager it really isn't for many people. 

I've played enough of the opening section of the game to confidently remove the game from my wishlist, but why is that? To me, it's really a matter of conflicting stances which fundamentally bothers me. 

It really feels like the game can't decide whether it wants to be this romantic medieval tale about an underdog rising through the world... and The Medieval Peasant Suffering Simulator‚Ñ¢. The mix just doesn't do it for me. I feel like I would really love this game if it were a true open sandbox game, where you could play out the painful and miserable lives of various characters you create. Instead, you are Henry, a man with a whole life and story, with a place in the world, with clear objectives and dreams... and then the game tells you "but actually, you can do whatever you want! :)".

If that sounds like a good time to you, then I highly recommend this game. The push and pull between these two stances simply makes me lose any interest in it.

The combat is lackluster, has poor responsiveness, and feels more jerky and slippery than smooth and forceful.
It feels like a M&B mod with Oblivion-esque UI that had the story fleshed out massively to where millions of people who didn't even know the Kingdom of Bohemia or the Cumans existed now do by virtue of this game's, and this game's predecessor's success; but ultimately failed to improve upon the combat in any real way from either the first game or M&B other than to add a fifth attack arc to the existing four.

Everything else about the game may be all well and good, and is to my limited experience; but the combat is so terrible even compared to Mount & Blade, which I would guess as the inspiration for the style of combat, that the game is a nuisance to play given that combat is offered as a viable option right from the tutorial by not only having it be listed as an archetype alongside Charisma and Stealth, but having the gall to put it as the initial option as well.
Hope you didn't tell the captain you were a soldier! Because if you did, you're rather fucked!
The speech-based option seems infinitely more viable given that combat is often avoidable anyway, and unlike other games where avoiding it is a choice you make; here the combat itself is so awful and clunky that it may as well be forcing you to avoid it. No wonder they added a dlc to give you high-end equipment early-on. You need it.
Even for a one-on-one you will struggle to block everything due to how finicky perfect-blocks are, despite the enemy rather often riposte-ing you.
Anything other than a one-on-one is basically impossible, as the game really wants to drive home how "only human" Henry is by making him extremely weak for how strong and effective he should be after the events of the previous game and the intervening time.

And you might stop and thing "well yes, that makes sense that it's hard to fight multiple people at once."
And you would be right.
If the game wasn't a sequel to another game where it's well established that your character is a capable fighter, even if you don't choose to have Henry be a career soldier; and yet this game expects it to be plausible that you can be dispatched and overwhelmed with ease by mediocre bandits with wood axes and peasants while you, a trained knight and bodyguard who has fought through hell just to survive, watch in dismay as yet another button input is delayed and your should-have-been perfect block leads to you being stun-locked to death yet again.

And then there's the stamina.
Now, I'm no trained knight or even in peak fitness; but I don't get lightheaded and woozy from swinging a sword five times. The stamina mechanic is just ridiculous, especially as Henry [i]is[/i] a trained knight and therefore likely [i]is[/i] in peak fitness, or near to it. It makes little-to-no sense that a few swings of a mere 1-3 pound short sword would tire Henry out unless he is intended to be asthmatic in the extreme and have hayfever year-round.

The developers have a clearly-ordained-and-intended way that you are supposed to engage in combat; that is by not doing so at all and fighting very defensively if you do.
And that is not fair to the players to try and force that upon them.
It's called [b]open[/b] world for a reason. That should include the whole game, mechanics and all; not just the world itself.

There is only one reason why I cannot recommend this game...at least for now.

And that's because of the ridiculous amount of buggy stuff going on in this game. The story is amazing, and the side quests are great, but all too often I find myself with a broken immersion when:

- I cannot really hunt well because animals move randomly af, and I mean backwards, sideways and sometimes they even fly off.

- I can't really commit crimes because NPCs are omniscient and will always blame you even if no one saw you, and if you try to stop them by killing all witnesses, they will still find out, and while chasing them they can literally teleport and go trough walls and fences.

- Mounted combat is completely broken and definitely not recommended. Despite having some perks available on the perk tree, the only viable way of fighting on a horse is from a distance and running away pretty much all the time because NPCs can run extremely fast without getting tired, even in full armor, all too often they might be even faster than your horse and then teleport to you, hit the horse and then dismount you, and charging them basically doesn't work at all.

- The DLC of the simthy is great, but every weapon that you forge literally looks the exact same. You only get to craft 3 types of things: short sword, long sword and an axe, and they all look the exact same. Even the axis that you're supposed to craft in the story quest is literally a short sword. They didn't even bother making a different mesh, not even for the main DLC quest, which feels incredibly bad, to be honest.

- And the most annoying bug of them all, happening all too often (I've already counted it 32 times in my playthrough, and that's when I started counting), is when suddenly my inventory gets bugged and I find myself in the middle of a fight, unable to change my weapon or drink any potions, even though I have them already equipped. The only way to fix this is to exit the game and re-launch it, because reloading a saved game will not fix the issue, and that means that all too often you will probably lose all your progress because of this random bug, and be unable to fight at all.

- Another mention I'd like to add is that melee combat happens on rails. You can only dodge attacks if the green shield pops up, and for some reason many times this will not happen, and enemies will hit you as if their weapons were heat seeking missiles, even if you're well outside of their range (they will literally teleport to you), which is incredibly annoying, and makes the dodging gameplay extremely unrewarding and overall, really buggy. In fact, many times you'll find yourself in a fight where you cannot win with skill, because the only way to block your enemy's attacks is by having invested enough money on your skill tree abilities with that weapon, or by training until you get a high enough level. You cannot win otherwise because your enemies will have essentially infinite stamina, strength and their attacks go towards you on rails. In the end, the best choice is a bow with poisonous arrows, which by the way is incredibly broken as well. You can down an entire army with just that.


So yeah, many people will think I'm being unfair because the game has a genuinely good story, but the game is so heavily scripted that it comes with a lot of stuff that will break the immersion, and that also makes the gameplay incredibly restrictive and linear. I'm not saying that the game is bad, all I'm saying is that it still needs a lot of work in order to feel like a polished, properly finished game, that's all.

And by the way, I'd gladly pay extra as long as this work gets properly done, after all, I've bought almost all the DLCs with the intention of supporting the developers, and trying the new content because I love the KCD series. But I really can't properly recommend this game until it's polished and released in a much better state.

[h1] Kingdome Come Deliverance II [/h1]

[i] or How to Turn a Masterpiece Passion Project into a Mass-Market AAA Slop [/i]

I recently played the second game for a little over 80 hours, and it's a complete disaster. While the gameplay changes are purely cosmetic or minor rehauls like the combat system, the core mechanics haven't changed much from the first game. What has changed is the narrative, writing, quest design, and overall tone of the game.

The serious narrative has been replaced by nonstop giggles about shit, how the main character stinks, how he gets doused with shit, and quests whose plots boil down to you getting drunk and doing stupid things. A huge number of nonsensical quests that don't fit into the narrative at all. They might have fit in the first game because Henry is just a peasant and can still go and do dumb funny quests where you have to paint a cow, but by the end of the first/beginning of the second game, he's already a respected person and has grown as a person, and narratively, it makes zero sense to even suggest those given the urgent mission plot going on. I could easily write a 3000-word essay here about every poorly written quest or just how this game as a whole is, but it all boils down to this.

- The narrative feels like Rockstar crap catered to normies, where all the quests are just random bullshit thrown in to amuse the player.
- The quests themselves are low-quality, linear, filler, fetch quest crap. There are only 1-2 interesting quests in the entire game so far, and even those are buggy. Unlike the quest design in the first game, the second game lacks any freedom or options for solving them. You're simply following a linear chain where you're not given any choices, with a couple of exceptions. And even the choices you do get are also extremely flat and plain simple. Although the second game has almost two to three times as many quests as the first, what's the point if they're all just undeveloped, linear crap?

And this quantity -> quality approach is evident in EVERY aspect of the sequel.

If you consider the game separately from the first game, it deserves an "okay" rating. 7/10, but as a sequel to the first game, it's a 4/10 at best. The first game was a carefully crafted handmade product born of passion with meticulous attention to detail, while the second game is a soulless, mass-produced product aimed at attracting a larger audience. And they succeeded. People lapped it up and are calling it Game of the Year. These are the same people for whom Game of the Year is yet another Assassin's Creed, Ghost of Tsushima, Grand Theft Auto, RDR, and other similar open-world slop games. It's truly sad that the second part saw such great success, as the industry has lost a talented studio forever.

A shame.

This game feels like it was made by two different studios. One wanted to make an uncompromising medieval immersive sim for sickos, the other wanted to make a pseudo-AAA 2000s-style linear cinematic game for as broad an audience as possible. KCD1 had a lot of the first thing and a bit of the second thing, in a way that added up to a flawed but special gem of a game that I loved a lot. After wrapping up the story I'd often boot it up just to hang out, ride around, go to a beautiful church.

In KCD2, the mouthbreathers won out. Much of KCD1's systems are recreated here, but everything is put towards a massive and interminable main quest so boring and stupid I had to force myself to keep playing in the hopes that Kuttenberg would be worth it. The dialogue and characters are painful. I'm asked to embody and care about the bizarre and myopic revenge quest of an extremely boring and horny asshole with a puzzlingly contemporary haircut. Apparently I'm best buds with Hans Capon, and my ability to hang out in this lovingly crafted rendition of medieval Bohemia is being held ransom by literally dozens of hours of straight-to-DVD buddy cop bullshit with this character I tolerated in KCD1 but grew to utterly loathe here. 

KCD1 wanted to be more like this, but lacked the resources for 8-hour railroaded main quests and lavish cutscenes. This was to its enormous benefit. Left to my own devices, I was able to role play myself in a medieval world. Things like the combat system that forced you to learn it or the fact that you had to literally learn to read thinned out the membrane between player and player character. It was the kind of game I'd wanted to play since I was a kid imagining what videogames might be like. 

In KCD2, there is never any chance to forget that you are playing Henry, and I don't care about Henry. Henry is a stupid person's idea of an interesting and realistic main character for a medieval RPG. I don't give a shit about him or his stupid dead stepdad. The game has no interest in getting me to care, and just assumes that I will feel the way it tells me I feel. His quest feels so much like a budget 2000s action movie that they even try to make a catchphrase happen‚Äîit's all in Latin, except for the word "fucking." 

And you can't go inside the fucking churches!

Meh.

Not recommended because it felt vastly different to the first game, and not in a good way. You never felt like a hero in KCD1, but in KCD2 Henry may as well be a fantasy character with power armour. Out of god knows how many speech skill checks I attempted, I only failed three of them and fought through so many 1vMany fights that it would make Master Chief blush. In the first game, I would get my ass handed to me if I tried fighting more than two enemies at once if I wasn't on horseback or from a superior vantage point. Here, I just slide in full heavy armour behind my opponents, putting my back to three guys, and slap each one silly like I'm Zorro or something.

It was very irritating putting in the work exploring the first region, building up a set of quality weapons and armour, slowly building up my money, and then you enter the second area and practically every enemy is now a fully kitted out elite mercenary wearing gold quality plate armour and using gold quality war grade weapons. If I ever play the game again, I will be rushing through the first area because it's pointless sticking around and smelling the roses, the second area just makes it completely redundant.

The environments were nice, but there was also a lot of liberties taken which were not taken in the first game. In the first game, I wandered for hours soaking in all of medieval brew, getting enthralled by simple things which had extensive lore entries such as a little clacking windmill on a small brook, but in this game this doesn't feel prominent at all. Whereas in KCD2 most of the landmarks you find are just dumb easter eggs or typical Bethesda game tier encounters. 

Where I was amazed and impressed by this new studio out of nowhere having such beautifully designed buildings and churches with extensive artistic interiors within with KCD1, here in KCD2 I never felt particularly thrilled or taken in by anything. You can't even enter churches in this one, they're all suspiciously closed and unmodelled inside! Though the castles you could explore were nice, I must admit. Kuttenburg was nice too, but came far too late in the game, in my opinion.

Also Sigismunds Warcamp was awful to traverse, which I had to do many times. Not being able to duck under cloth walls, or slice through them, or even vault over them, just added to the annoyance.

Adequate as far as games go, for sure, but miserly for a medieval simulator, as it truly feels like it gave way to fantasy or generic adventure instead of a proper simulation, but not a very good one, as it's hobbled by the fact it tries to present itself as a serious medieval adventure.

Story is also heavily railroaded, in part due to the fact important NPCs respawn - early "major" quest involves Henry and Hans visiting a fortress to affirm its loyalty, with Hans going to meet the leader and leaving you to your own devices. It quickly becomes obvious that the people in the fort are suspiciously trying to make you waste your time there and keep you occupied, so I decided to snoop around, and found a whole heap of evidence that they were up to no good. After this, (and conveniently after Steam's refund timer), the real game begins, and there are many frustrations.

The save system leaves me questioning the design choices immediately, I'm not allowed to save unless I brew some potion that lets me, BUT I can "save and quit" at any point, leading to moments where I just need to quit to save and then load the game again.  Extremely pointless.

The combat is rather static, wooden, doesn't feel realistic or dynamic in any way.  It feels like something from the old era of gaming like Gothic etc.  It's just a matter of block/parry/attack rinse and repeat.

Then there's a forced first-person-view.  Why?  I want to see my character and the armour I've equipped, and I don't like all the forced camera movements in FPV when doing EVERY SINGLE ACTION.  it's like press a button, wait for 2 seconds while the camera moves around weirdly before you can do anything else.

As well as this, there are a lot of weird key binding choices, like sometimes I have to just press ESC to cancel something and other times I have to hold ESC for 1 second?  The same with E, or whatever.  Why?  This is confusing and un-intuitive and completely non-standard for PC key bindings.

And to top it all off, once I had managed to actually get to grips with some of the game systems and kill a small camp with 3 bandits in it near the starting area, I loaded myself up with their weapons and armour then proceeded down the hill to find 3 "wild dogs".  I got my ass absolutely beaten raw by these three wild dogs.  A man in armour, with swords, can't beat 3 dogs.  Right.

I also have issues with the stealth system, lockpicking, item equipping (you have 3 sets of equipment, and all of it ALSO stays in your inventory for maximum clutter), item stat comparison, and the combat system.  All of them feel clunky and at times like I'm not in control: the character and/or the UI feel unresponsive during actions quite a lot.

As a point of comparison with all of the above, I've been playing a lot of Mount & Blade 2 recently, and let me tell you that game does a lot of these things right, and overall has a MUCH better feel to playing it than KCD2.  It has a great first, and third-person views.  Amazing fluid and fast feel to the combat, 3 armour sets you can actually equip properly without cluttering up your inventory, and an easy to understand stat comparison for equipment.

So, I've modded this game now so I can save any time I want, and I have an optional TPV (which is pretty bad because the game hasn't been designed for it) but I'm hoping I can struggle my way through to find this supposedly "game of the year" content that people are going on about.

So far, it's very pretty, but every other thing about the game has frustrated me and feels clunky.  I will see how far I can get, but really not finding myself compelled to come back to play.  I unfortunately wouldn't find myself recommending this to my friends.
